Finance 238 examines the available corporate securities that firms can use to finance investment. The course will focus on the design of these securities (Why do bonds have embedded options? What is the role of preferred stock?), the issuing process for these securities (What do investment banks do? Is the underwriting process important for the cost of capital?), the pricing of these securities (How are credit risk in bonds and loans priced?) The securities covered include corporate and junk bonds, bank loans, common and preferred equity, commercial paper, securitization, as well as some recent innovations. Other topics include: the role of embedded options in corporate bonds, the role of bank and loan covenants, the function of bond rating agencies, exchange offers; prepackaged bankruptcies, bankruptcy, workouts, debtor-in-possession financing, and pricing credit risk. The course is designed to be complementary to Advanced Corporate Finance and Fixed Income Securities.

The reviews for this course were overwhelmingly positive. Students described the class using words such as “fantastic” and “understandable.” Students thought that the material was practical and that the information would prove useful to their future careers. One student wrote that it was the best class they had taken at Wharton. 

The majority of students seemed to adore Professor Musto. They praised him for his “clarity” and his ability to simplify concepts. One student wrote that through his “calm, collected lectures he conveys the information quite well to his students.” Students felt that he was incredibly informative. Several students commented that Professor Musto was their favorite professor at Wharton. 

In terms of audience, one student wrote that this is a “great course for students interested in Wall Street.” Another student highlighted, however, that this is an overview course, warning that it does not go into much depth. In terms of workload, students felt that the structure of quizzes every other week relieved a lot of stress and, in general, students felt that the grading was fair.  One student mentioned that the cases were dense with legal terms, and warned international students to maybe take another class if their English is not strong. FNCE 100 and FNCE 101 are prerequisites for this course.
